content:
吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed neque elit, tristique placerat feugiat ac, facilisis vitae arcu. Proin eget egestas augue. Praesent ut sem nec arcu pellentesque aliquet. Duis dapibus diam vel metus tempus vulputate.
summary: 吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
title: 吳恩達

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
This analysis is going to explore some of the different circumstances behind fatal police shootings in where the victim was fleeing.
Type of FleeingFigure 1 below shows the proportion of those who do not flee, who do, and if they are fleeing, what method of fleeing that these individuals are using.
#proportion are killed while attempting to fleeshootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ flee + year, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(proportion = count / sum(count)) %>%ggplot() +geom_line(mapping = aes(x = year, y = proportion, color = flee)) +ggtitle("Proportion of Fatal Police Shooting by Flee Method") + xlab("Year") + ylab("Proportion") + theme_bw()Figure 1.The proportion of fatal police shootings by flee method over time.
Figure 1 depicts the proportion of fleeing by car decreasing and every other method is seen increasing, in recent. The proportion of the incidents where fleeing method is not recorded is increasing every year, almost to the same degree that the “Not Fleeing” method is decreasing, this should be taken into account.
shootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%filter(armed == "unarmed") %>%aggregate(count ~ flee + year + armed, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(proportion = count / sum(count)) %>%ggplot(mapping = aes(x=year, y = proportion, color = flee)) +geom_line() +ggtitle("Breakdown of Unarmed Victims") + xlab("Year") + ylab("Proportion") + theme_bw() Figure 2. Accounts for the proportion of method of fleeing of unarmed victims of fatal police shootings
unarmed <- shootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%filter(armed == "unarmed") %>%aggregate(count ~ flee + year + armed, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(proportion = count / sum(count)) %>%select(-armed, -count) %>%datatable()htmlwidgets::saveWidget(unarmed, file = "unarmed.html", selfcontained = TRUE)Table 1.A table of the proportion of unarmed victims by fleeing method
summary:
This analysis is going to explore some of the different circumstances behind fatal police shootings in where the victim was fleeing.
Type of FleeingFigure 1 below shows the proportion of those who do not flee, who do, and if they are fleeing, what method of fleeing that these individuals are using.
title: Fleeing

content:
Threat and RaceThere has always been a debate between the links of fatal police shootings and victims. There has even been insinuations that race has an effect on the threatening nature of these individuals. This topic often sparks outrage within the black and POC communities and within law enforcement.
I’m going to try to explore this sensitive topic and try to make some inferential findings.
The DataThe dataset can be found here.
We have three variables to look at: “attack”, “other”, and “undetermined”. Attack constitutes as the individual was reported to have posed immediate threat to the officer. “Other” is every other level of threat and “undetermined” is for any circumstance that through the vetting process, threat level could not be determined.Keep in mind how the level of threat is determined, as explained in the home page.
Let’s look at the visualization of the raw numbers/counts. Figure 1 below shows the level of reported threat by race.
shootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%ggplot() +geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = threat_level, fill = race), position = "dodge") +facet_wrap(~threat_level, scales = "free") + ggtitle("Raw Amounts of Threat Level") +xlab("Threat Level") +ylab("Count")Figure 1.Amount of Fatal Police Shootings by Race since 2015
All three graphs look identical. The only visual difference is the volume of the counts. I think in this case, looking at the proportions will be more inferenital.
r.proportion <- shootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%mutate(year = year(date)) %>%aggregate(count ~ threat_level + race + year, data = ., sum) %>%filter(threat_level == "attack") %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(race.proportion = count / sum(count))r.proportion %>%ggplot() +geom_boxplot(mapping = aes(x = race, y = race.proportion), fill = "lavender") +geom_point(mapping = aes(x = race, y = race.proportion, color = year)) +ggtitle("Proportion of Race with 'attack' Threat Level") + xlab("Race") +ylab("Proportion") + theme_bw()Figure 2.Box plot and distribution of the proportions of victims who are recorded to have posed a threat to an officer’s life by race from 2015 to current.
r.proportion %>%lm(formula = race.proportion ~ race * year, data = .) -> modelr.proportion## # A tibble: 42 x 5## # Groups: year [6]## threat_level race year count race.proportion## <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>## 1 attack Asian 2015 10 0.0137 ## 2 attack Black 2015 183 0.25 ## 3 attack Hispanic 2015 106 0.145 ## 4 attack Native 2015 6 0.00820## 5 attack NR 2015 21 0.0287 ## 6 attack Other 2015 9 0.0123 ## 7 attack White 2015 397 0.542 ## 8 attack Asian 2016 5 0.00923## 9 attack Black 2016 147 0.271 ## 10 attack Hispanic 2016 88 0.162 ## # ... with 32 more rowsr.proportion %>%ggplot(aes(x= race, y = race.proportion, color = year)) +geom_point() +stat_smooth(method = "lm")## `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'summary(model)## ## Call:## lm(formula = race.proportion ~ race * year, data = .)## ## Residuals:## Min 1Q Median 3Q Max ## -0.044770 -0.005817 0.000253 0.006384 0.061749 ## ## Coefficients:## Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) ## (Intercept) -8.489e-01 1.091e+01 -0.078 0.938515 ## raceBlack 2.009e+01 1.542e+01 1.303 0.203255 ## raceHispanic 1.224e+01 1.542e+01 0.793 0.434228 ## raceNative 2.786e+00 1.542e+01 0.181 0.857969 ## raceNR -9.710e+01 1.542e+01 -6.295 8.30e-07 ***## raceOther 3.337e+00 1.542e+01 0.216 0.830268 ## raceWhite 6.558e+01 1.542e+01 4.252 0.000213 ***## year 4.277e-04 5.406e-03 0.079 0.937503 ## raceBlack:year -9.848e-03 7.645e-03 -1.288 0.208271 ## raceHispanic:year -6.000e-03 7.645e-03 -0.785 0.439186 ## raceNative:year -1.382e-03 7.645e-03 -0.181 0.857877 ## raceNR:year 4.818e-02 7.645e-03 6.302 8.15e-07 ***## raceOther:year -1.657e-03 7.645e-03 -0.217 0.829991 ## raceWhite:year -3.229e-02 7.645e-03 -4.223 0.000230 ***## ---## Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1## ## Residual standard error: 0.02262 on 28 degrees of freedom## Multiple R-squared: 0.9862, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9798 ## F-statistic: 154.2 on 13 and 28 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16ANOVA.threat = aov(model)# Tukey test to study each pair of treatment :TUKEY <- TukeyHSD(x=ANOVA.threat, 'race', conf.level=0.95, ordered = TRUE)## Warning in replications(paste("~", xx), data = mf): non-factors ignored: year## Warning in replications(paste("~", xx), data = mf): non-factors ignored: race,## year# Tuckey test representation :plot(TUKEY , las=1 , col="brown")TUKEY## Tukey multiple comparisons of means## 95% family-wise confidence level## factor levels have been ordered## ## Fit: aov(formula = model)## ## $race## diff lwr upr p adj## Native-Other 0.003723252 -0.03769474 0.04514125 0.9999473## Asian-Other 0.005536265 -0.03588173 0.04695426 0.9994714## NR-Other 0.111432473 0.07001448 0.15285047 0.0000001## Hispanic-Other 0.138572099 0.09715410 0.17999009 0.0000000## Black-Other 0.233035326 0.19161733 0.27445332 0.0000000## White-Other 0.448440663 0.40702267 0.48985866 0.0000000## Asian-Native 0.001813012 -0.03960498 0.04323101 0.9999993## NR-Native 0.107709221 0.06629123 0.14912722 0.0000001## Hispanic-Native 0.134848847 0.09343085 0.17626684 0.0000000## Black-Native 0.229312074 0.18789408 0.27073007 0.0000000## White-Native 0.444717410 0.40329941 0.48613541 0.0000000## NR-Asian 0.105896208 0.06447821 0.14731420 0.0000002## Hispanic-Asian 0.133035834 0.09161784 0.17445383 0.0000000## Black-Asian 0.227499061 0.18608107 0.26891706 0.0000000## White-Asian 0.442904398 0.40148640 0.48432239 0.0000000## Hispanic-NR 0.027139626 -0.01427837 0.06855762 0.3917831## Black-NR 0.121602853 0.08018486 0.16302085 0.0000000## White-NR 0.337008190 0.29559019 0.37842619 0.0000000## Black-Hispanic 0.094463227 0.05304523 0.13588122 0.0000014## White-Hispanic 0.309868564 0.26845057 0.35128656 0.0000000## White-Black 0.215405337 0.17398734 0.25682333 0.0000000# I need to group the treatments that are not different each other together.label_df <- function(TUKEY, variable){# Extract labels and factor levels from Tukey post-hoc levels <- TUKEY[[variable]][,4]Tukey.labels <- data.frame(multcompLetters(levels)['Letters'])#I need to put the labels in the same order as in the boxplot :Tukey.labels$treatment=rownames(Tukey.labels)Tukey.labels=Tukey.labels[order(Tukey.labels$treatment) , ]return(Tukey.labels)}# Apply the function on my datasetLABELS <- label_df(TUKEY , "race")# A panel of colors to draw each group with the same color :my_colors <- c( rgb(143,199,74,maxColorValue = 255),rgb(242,104,34,maxColorValue = 255), rgb(111,145,202,maxColorValue = 255),rgb(151,105,102,maxColorValue = 255))# Draw the basic boxplota <- boxplot(r.proportion$race.proportion ~ r.proportion$race, ylim=c(min(r.proportion$race.proportion) , 1.1*max(r.proportion$race.proportion)) , col=my_colors[as.numeric(LABELS[,1])] , ylab="value" , main="")## Warning in boxplot.default(split(mf[[response]], mf[-response], drop = drop, :## NAs introduced by coercion# I want to write the letter over each box. Over is how high I want to write it.over <- 0.1*max( a$stats[nrow(a$stats),] )#Add the labelstext( c(1:nlevels(r.proportion$race)) , a$stats[nrow(a$stats),]+over , LABELS[,1] , col = my_colors[as.numeric(LABELS[,1])] )## Warning in text.default(c(1:nlevels(r.proportion$race)),## a$stats[nrow(a$stats), : NAs introduced by coercion
summary: Threat and RaceThere has always been a debate between the links of fatal police shootings and victims. There has even been insinuations that race has an effect on the threatening nature of these individuals.
title: Threat and Race

content:
Mental IllnessThere’s a statistic that people mental illness are 15 times more likely to be shot in a police encounter than the lay person. We can think about people like Shukri Ali Said who’s sister called 911 for aid when Said had a mental break. Police had found Said at an intersection with a knife and shot her 5 times, resulting in her death. We can think about Saheed Vassell. A man with a recorded mental illness, who also had a fatal police shooting. Vassell pointed a pipe at a police officer and was shot. We can think about the many people with mental and intellectual illnesses who had fatal police encounters and think about the possible different roots of the problem; the history of social stigma of treatment, to the processes of deinstitutionalization, to the defunding of existing community services like education, affordable housing, social and health services.
This post is going to explore the effects of mental illness and fatal police encounters.
General StatisticsYou can find the dataset here.
mental.illness <- shootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ race + signs_of_mental_illness + year, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(race, signs_of_mental_illness) %>%summarise(mean = mean(count),sd = sd(count),min = min(count),max = max(count)) ## `summarise()` regrouping output by 'race' (override with `.groups` argument)d1 <- mental.illness %>%datatable()Table 1General descriptive statistics of fatal police shootings overall.
ag.year <- shootings %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ race + signs_of_mental_illness + year, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(race, signs_of_mental_illness, year) %>%summarise(mean = mean(count))## `summarise()` regrouping output by 'race', 'signs_of_mental_illness' (override with `.groups` argument)d2 <- ag.year %>%datatable()ag.year %>%ggplot() +geom_point(mapping = aes(x = race, y = mean), color = "gray") +geom_boxplot(mapping = aes(x = race, y = mean, fill = signs_of_mental_illness)) +theme_bw() + ggtitle("Average Shootings by Mental Illness") + xlab("Race") + ylab("Average")Figure 1Boxplot of the mean fatal police encounters by race over the years.
Table 2Mean of police shooting by race aggregated by year.
In the two tables shown above, we get a good picture fatal police shootings by signs of mental illness, from the years 2015 to current day. White people make up more than 70% of the US population, so it makes sense that white people will make up the most of police shootings in just raw numbers. Look at Figure 1 for the example. If we do some data crunching, we wil see something interesting. Since 2015, even though white people make up more than 70% of the population, 45% of fatal shootings involve white victims, which is disproportionate. If we factor in mental illness, overall, almost 30% of the white victims of fatal police shootings showed signs of mental illness. Of black victims: 14.3%, of asian: 24.7%, of hispanic: 17.2%, of native american: 17.9%. Overall, 28.9% of fatal police shooting victims are recorded as showing signs of mental illness.
De-escalation?If more than 1 in 4 victims of fatal police shootings involve mental illness, were there attempts to subdue these victims besides shooting? The dataset I’m working with involve whether a taser was used to de-escalate along with shooting via the variable manner_of_death. There were only two categories, shot, and, shot and Tasered.
shootings %>%filter(signs_of_mental_illness == "True") %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ manner_of_death + year, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(prop = count / sum(count)) %>%ggplot() +geom_line(mapping = aes(x = year, y = prop, color = manner_of_death)) +theme_bw() + xlab("Year") + ylab("Proportion") + ggtitle("Victims with Mental Illness")Figure 1.
In Figure 2, we see that with the fatal police shootings involving victims that showed signs of mental illness, less than 10% in every year have on record that the police tried to deploy a taser as a means of subduing the victim. we actually see a dip in 2018 and is slowly starting to rise again. We are only through a little more than half of the year, but this dataset is updated real time, so this graph will always be current.
shootings %>%filter(signs_of_mental_illness == "True", manner_of_death == "shot and Tasered") %>%mutate(count = 1) %>%aggregate(count ~ manner_of_death + year + race, data = ., sum) %>%group_by(year) %>%mutate(prop = count / sum(count)) %>%ggplot() +geom_smooth(mapping = aes(x = year, y = prop, color = race)) +theme_bw() + xlab("Year") + ylab("Proportion") + ggtitle("Victims with Mental Illness by Race")Figure 3Taser deployed with victims showing signs of mental illness by race
Figure 3 offers more insight. Overall, through all years, white victims that involve deployment of a taser: 47.8%, native american: 1.11%, hispanic: 17.8%, black: 23.3%, asian: 3.3%. We also see that the proportion of the use and deployment of a taser is more steadily increasing among black and white victims, those who make up the majority of victims of fatal police shootings. The percentage of hispanic victims look to be increasing to a small degree, but it may be attributed to the decrease in proportion of victims with race not being recorded.
ConclusionWith almost 28.9% of all fatal police shootings involve the victims showing signs of mental illness. Of those instances, less than 10% every year are recorded that other means than just shooting a gun were used to subdue the victim. Figure 3 shows the ratio of those instances by race with white and black percentages increasing since 2018.
It still begs the question. If 28.9% of victims of fatal police shootings show signs of mental illness, why do 10% of those cases have other means besides shooting as a way to subdue these individuals? I do think it is important to note that certain states have banned the use of tasers. However, could these instances of mental breaks or threatening individuals with mental illnesses been avoided all together? Should we have invested more in social services and health services? These are questions that can’t be answered with this dataset alone.
summary: Mental IllnessThere’s a statistic that people mental illness are 15 times more likely to be shot in a police encounter than the lay person. We can think about people like Shukri Ali Said who’s sister called 911 for aid when Said had a mental break.
title: Exploration of Mental Illness and Fatal Police Shootings

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides
